John,

thanks for the reply...wish we were all at a whiteboard together in 
which case we could come up with an elegant solution rather 
quickly...

I understand all that you said, but it still creates problems.  The 
idea of recurrency is that it stores a memory that allows the net to 
anticipate and strategize based on a prior world state. 

Suppose I follow your idea of activating the net in several steps, 
moving my agent in those time steps if the net says to do it, but 
not checking the new world state.  

After these several timesteps, I assume I should re-initialize the 
inputs to all the neurons to zero.  Then I re-scan the "world", get 
my inputs, and do it all again.  But this resetting and rescanning 
implies no memory of a prior world state since in our internal 
timesteps we did not consider the world inputs again until we were 
done with our net activation.  Does this make sense?  

I have come up with my own way to handle this and I'm coding it 
as we speak.  Following is what I propose:

1) I do exactly what John suggested, I have a nice and tight
recursive routine that quickly determines dependencies, which 
includes recursive dependencies

2) I then activate each neuron that has all its depedencies 
fulfilled/processed iteratively, unitl ALL neurons have been 
processed.  I also process recurrent links here, BUT if it is
timestep 0, i store the recurrent value in its own place separate 
from the neurons non-recurrent, total inputs.  Importantly, at 
timestep 0 these recurrent weights are NOT considered in the 
firing/non-firing decision of the neuron.

3) if the output neurons tell the agent to move, it does so.

4) reset ALL the neurons...BUT, if its not timestep 0, then keep the 
recurrent totals in the neurons that had a recurrent link back to 
them..otherwise erset all neurons totals including recurrent totals

5) get the new state of the world..meaning read the input values..

6) process the net as above...if it is not timestep 0, then when 
making a fire/not-fire decision, we total the inputs for a neuron
PLUS the recurrent values from the last net execution....so this is 
the memory of the prior state being used.

7) repeat all the above...

This seems like a practical approach to me that should work, 
although I haven't got it working yet.. The code to fire the 
network, even knowing dependencies, is a little tricky.

Hope this all makes some sense...hard to describe via written note...

--Kevin
